title: Twice-Cooked Pork
description: A classic Sichuan-inspired twice-cooked pork featuring tender boiled pork belly sliced and stir-fried until sizzling with spicy fermented bean paste, sweet bell pepper and scallions. Rich, savory, and slightly smoky with a balanced heat and umami finish.

ingredients.display_name: pork belly (skin removed if desired) cut into 2-3 in piece for boiling
ingredients.notes: 1 piece (~800 g); will be boiled then sliced
enough to cover pork in pot

ingredients.display_name: scallions (white and green separated, whites chopped, greens cut into 2-inch lengths)
ingredients.notes: use whites for aromatics, greens for garnish

ingredients.display_name: fresh ginger, peeled and thinly sliced
ingredients.notes: thin slices for boiling and stir-fry

ingredients.display_name: dried red chilies (optional for extra heat)
sichuan doubanjiang (fermented broad bean and chili paste)
bell pepper (red or green), seeded and thickly sliced

steps.text: Prepare pork by trimming excess rind if desired and rinse; place pork belly in a pot large enough to cover and add water, half the sliced ginger, half the scallion whites and a pinch of salt.
Bring water to a boil over high heat, then reduce to a simmer and poach the pork gently until just cooked through and tender enough to slice, about 25 minutes depending on thickness.
Remove pork from broth and let rest until cool enough to handle; reserve 100–200 ml of the poaching liquid for later if needed for deglazing or thinning sauce.
Slice the cooled pork belly thinly (2–3 mm) across the grain into bite-sized slices; arrange on a plate ready for frying.

Heat a large wok or heavy skillet over high heat until smoking slightly, add vegetable oil and spread; add remaining ginger, garlic, dried chilies if using and the remaining scallion whites; stir-fry briefly (20–30 seconds) until aromatic.

Add sliced pork to the hot wok in a single layer if possible and stir-fry over high heat until edges begin to brown and render slightly, about 3–4 minutes. Work in batches if needed to avoid crowding.
Push pork to the side and add doubanjiang; fry the paste in the oil for 20–30 seconds to bloom the flavors, then mix with the pork to coat evenly.

Add sliced bell pepper (if using), soy sauce, rice wine, sugar and reserved poaching liquid as needed to create a glossy sauce; stir-fry until peppers are just tender-crisp and sauce clings to pork, about 2–3 minutes.
Taste and adjust seasoning with salt; finish with a drizzle of toasted sesame oil and fold in scallion greens just before removing from heat.
Transfer to a serving platter and serve hot with steamed rice and optional greens.
